I recently subscribed to your channel, great videos by the way, and I came across this. I worked in geothermal reservoirs where we encounter similar capillary pressure measured values in the geothermal reservoir rocks because of the tiny pore throats like you mentioned in your video. I however, need to point out a confusing part in your video. At time stamp 2:21 you mentioned that the xylem tubes are 20-200 micrometers in diameter. And yet later on you said that the “pores” transporting the water, which I assume you meant the xylem tubes are only 2-2.5 nanometers in diameter. That’s a difference of about 10,000 times. So which one is it? I believe it is the later and at these distances your video is correct, the electrostatic forces of the molecules of water are able to hold the meniscus at much higher pressures. But then this is the definition of capillary pressure. In geothermal rocks there is the additional effect of salts contained in the water at the pores and this results in even higher capillary pressures measured for a given size of the pore throat because of the additional electrostatic charge lent by the salt ions in solution.

a more accurate, though admittedly less baity title: "How trees conform exactly to the laws of physics."

Winter = tree is hibernating
Spring = tree is prepping, soaking up water and fresh nutrients
Summer = tree then uses the spring’s staging and the summer’s heat to squeeze the water up in INCREMENTS from day to day heat cycles.
Fall = tree shutting down those processes to prepare for a freezing/cold/less sunny winter.

I like to think of a tree’s “breathing cycles” not in days, as we humans love to measure time out in increments of days, but that a tree’s “breathing cycle” happens over a 365 day period. That is, is it not possible that it may have more to do with the heat of the warmer days effecting the whole trunk of the tree, perhaps creating more pressure inside of the trunk during the nicer half of the year?
So in other words, maybe it’s more like a tree soaks up water into its root system and base of the trunk, near its burl where the root-ball meets the trunk, AND THEN as the weather heats up and the trunk and the top half of the tree gets warmer and warmer through the warm season it may then creat higher pressure within the tree’s trunk to help with squeezing the water up.

So once a xylem tube gets damaged and has air introduced to it, it will never function again?

This is utter nonsense. There is no such thing as negative pressure. You got close to the truth when you compared the water in the xylem cells to a cord under tension. The curved surface where water evaporates at the leaf is under enormous tension. When a molecule of water departs by evaporating, there is a tremendous force to restore that interface's shape vs. letting it become even more curved. That force pulls a water molecule from below, and because the cohesive forces between the water molecules is so much greater than between them and the xylem walls, the water is pulled under tension as if it was a continuous solid string reaching down.

To say that there is negative pressure is a silly idea, as if there is negative pressure at the top of the string when I pull on it. The whole string rises when I pull the top because of the cohesive forces that hold the string together. It's the same with water, and each tiny "pull" is from an intensely strained curved interface restoring itself as a water molecule departs via evaporation. We're just not used to thinking of water having enough cohesive force for a 100-meter long "string" of it to be pulled from the top. But in narrow enough channels with the necessary wall interactions with water, it does.

There are no trees that generate negative-15 water-pressure. the cells of the wood simply use capillary action of water tension to absorb water up a series of wood fibers, and dump it into another cell. It requires only a minimal negative pressure, 0.001 atmosphere, the only limit is the structural integrity of the wood at the base of the tree, to carry the weight of the wet wood above it. When dry, the dead center wood of the tree acts as a reservoir to keep the thin layer of new growth alive, the only part of the tree that is alive, and actively multiplying cells. It's a series of reservoirs, and evaporative diffusion through water tension on capillary fibers. Where did you get this idea of negative pressure?

I have a theory that goes like this:

A little capillary action gets it up. The heartwood (center) is dead, and is there for structure, and the sap wood takes up the water. The bark and heartwood are not flexible, but The sap wood gets squeezed by them and keeps the capillary action going up the tree. If you take the bark off the tree in a growing season, it’s actually super slippery allowing movement like expansion. But if it rains too much and the bark hasn’t matured enough, tree bark will sometimes split. It may heal, but it also could leave a branch to die above it. Coppicing (removing a few feet of bark around the trunk) kills a tree.

I find it is more useful to think about the lowest-level basics: How the forces are communicated between atoms and between molecules, namely *virtual photons*. When pressure in the water is positive, the virtual photons push the molecules apart. When pressure in the water is negative, even a little bit negative, the virtual photons push the molecules together. This means that the water pressure never has to get extremely negative, like the stated -15 atmospheres. Negative pressure should be thought of as a *virtual pressure*. As a not-quite-real thing, negative virtual pressure will not boil water.
Still not clear? Think about a bar of steel being stretched under tension, which is a LOT of tension by the time you may notice the stretching. In 'freedom units' that force is expressed in pounds [force] per square inch (PSI), where 1 atmosphere is about 15 PSI. Does steel under a tension load of 150,000 PSI have an internal pressure of -10,000 atmospheres? It can be figured that way in an equation, but does it really explain WHY the steel did not snap at much lower strain? Virtual photons DO explain why.

The purpose of all the water evaporating is to dissipate heat; to keep the top portions of the tree from becoming sun-burned. Imagine if trees didn't do this. Well, there wouldn't be any trees at all. There would only be shrubs growing on the shady side of mountains.
The dissipation of heat and sun's energy is so much more important than simply keeping the trees from getting burned. The whole forest floor beneath the trees relies on this as well. The life on the ground, even the ground itself, lends to the survival of the trees. Think trees don't have a consciousness? Maybe they do afterall. I don’t think this explanation is completely correct.
I attended a lecture in 1977 where the tree expert postulated that the xylem water column in not continuous from root to leaf, but it has “stages” where it does ion exchanges with the phylem and thus equalises the pressure. In this way the water is “pumped up” from the roots in several stages, like a multi-stage pump.
The theory that the water column is established when the tree is young and is “stretched” by tree growth to tens of meters in length does not rhyme with the fact that the xylem is continuously being replaced by new growth. Also this supposed continuous water column will not survive drought situations. What happens when there is not enough water at the roots? (happens most summers!) The negative pressure on the root cells would likely destroy them. I don’t have any real evidence, but my common sense says that this explanation is at most only half the story.

That 95% evaporation isn't for nothing. It is the cooling mechanism for the plant or trees. When the water evaporates it cools the surface temperature of the leaves which helps protect the leaves and promote photosynthesis. Different species have different temperature and humidity requirements and also different requirements for stages of growth like vegetative and flowering. For example,  the flowering stage typically likes an increase in heat and decrease in humidity which promotes more transpiration hence more nutrients and water provided to the flowers, or fruit.

completely disagree here... he rejects capillary action as a hypothesis on the basis that the xylem is a large diameter water column, but the diameter of the column itself doesn't matter. What's important is the diameter of each air-water interface, cause that's where you get the surface tension. He said it himself, pore size is 2-5 nm well within the scope of capillary action. if people still disagree, try this, use a thick pipe or hose and diverge it into smaller and smaller tubes until you get  to capillary tubes. Use fittings or Plasticine to seal  each transition (it needs to be air-tight to prevent air-water interfaces. push water through the hose until you get water out of the capillaries (capillary action doesn't set in until the air-water interface moves to the smaller diameter, and you should see that the entire system holds water  even when stretched out. what you just created my friend is a model of the water system in a tree which works using capillary action. I mean you say that it's a negative absolute pressure, not really it's just capillary action.

Cacti etc. Use CAM, while lots of Med/Tropical plants use C4. most evergreen are C3, the ‘basic’ method. C3 is quicker and ‘cheaper’ in terms of energy cost per CO2 fixed but is less viable in hotter, drier climates.

4:29 Why do trees only use 5% of the water they transport? To survive:
"To make sugars, plants must absorb CO2 from the atmosphere through small pores in their leaves called stomata. However, when stomata open, water is lost to the atmosphere at a prolific rate relative to the small amount of CO2 absorbed; across plant species an average of 400 water molecules are lost for each CO2 molecule gained. The balance between transpiration and photosynthesis forms an essential compromise in the existence of plants; stomata must remain open to build sugars but risk dehydration in the process."

Trees don't evaporate most of their water into the atmosphere for fun. The leaves can absorb carbon from the air, but all the other elements needed for growing can only be absorbed by the roots from the ground. Plants don't have hearts to circulate blood through their bodies, so when the nutrient rich water has reached the leaves, it does not have any means to return the water back to the roots. So it just evaporates the water into the air and sucks up new water from the ground.

it's a nice theory, but the truth is much simpler. Every day, as the Earth rotates (because of science), the trees will spend half of any given day (day being 24 hour period) upside down. It's not a rocket science then to realize that the water (H2O) will simply flow "downhill" into the tree tops. This is a well documented water behavior-water always does this. The only time when water doesn't behave in such a way is when the water is gas (water gas - the "O" in "H2O") which naturally rises rather than flows down.

You have stated at 1.31: -
“Scientists who study trees find that xylem tubes that transport water, do contain a continuous water column.”
Hence the Hydrostatic Pressure at the base of a 100 meter tall tree is approx. 760 x 10 = 7,600 mmHg.
The external atmospheric pressure is 760 mmHg.
So the xylem at the base of the tree are confronted with a massive Pressure Differential across their walls of 7,600 – 760 = 6,840 mmHg.

So my question to you is; - How is it possible for the single cell walled xylem to contain such a massive pressure of 6,840 mmHg, without blowing out, like the varicose veins in our human legs?

2) I used to watch your videos when you were asking people scientific questions and they were giving incorrect answers and thinking to myself "Why don't I ever get asked these things? I'd nail it!" Watching Hank here really makes me think that I would do much worse than my ego would like to admit. It is very important to recognize the limits of your knowledge, and never be afraid to say you don't know. Do not assert with confidence as fact an untested hypothesis.
As a wise man once said "the beginning of wisdom starts with saying I don't know." Use this to focus your learning to continually broaden your understanding of the world around you.

I'm having a hard time with the concept of a negative absolute pressure. You cannot buy a gauge for such a pressure. Pressure is proportional to the number of molecular collision per second with the vessel wall.  Heat a gas or confine a liquid and the pressure rises. If you could get a perfect vacuum you could get that down to 0 collisions per second once the vessel contained no matter.  That would be 0 psia or -14.696 psig (gauge pressure reads 0.0 in air at sea level).  You cannot get less than 0 collisions per second and could only approach that depending on how well you could evacuate a vessel. While the pressure of water (sap) might be less than atmospheric pressure in leaves or in the the stem, a tall tree must must operate in stages assuming the root don't develop enough pressure to pump it to the top elevation of the tree.

Just in Case someone didn't understand the thing with the negative pressure (well I didn't), some exlaination:
Pressure is just a physical concept. It says how strong molekuels are pushing you away. So lets say you have a wall with athmospheric pressure on side A and vakuum on side B. Side A is pushing against the wall, while the vakuum is simply not. This vakuum is NOT draging the wall, its simply not pushing. So vakuum is zero pressure by definition. But imagine what happens if side B is draging. Thats negative pressure then. But this is only possible due to cohesion of an liquid (the same force/effect that ensures that waterdrops dont fall apart). On smaller scales cohesion is more impactfull than on bigger scales (compare the shape of big and small waterdrops), so on those very small scales like the diameter of a xylem, the cohesion can actually be responsible for very big negative pressures.

Based on the most recent research, the hypothesis in the video is wrong.  If the hypothesis were correct then we would find 300+ foot trees everywhere.  But we know that's not the case. The crucial factor left out of the video was the geographic location of the trees under discussion.

The tallest trees, including the 100+ meter trees in the video, do not transport water from the roots to the top but absorb it from the atmosphere.  The tallest trees are found along the West Coast where large amounts of water in the form of fog off of the Pacific flows through the tops of the trees.  The trees' needles are especially adapted to take in that water thus eliminating the need for the tree to transport water from the roots 300+ ft. to the top.

So I am a little confused. In high school, we made a mercury barometer using a glass tube that was open on one end and closed on the other. With the closed end down, we filled with the tube with mercury. We then sealed the open end, inverted the tube, and submerged the open end in a dish of mercury. Then we removed the seal and the mercury dropped to barometric pressure (about 30"). Like the tree, we didn't try to suck the mercury up the tube, the tube was completely full of mercury when we started. What was in the glass tube above the mercury in the homemade barometer? We were told a near complete vacuum. Almost 0 atmospheres. Why wouldn't there have been -15 atmospheres in the glass tube, with the mercury remaining at the top of the tube (like the water in the tree xylem), instead of sinking down to about 30"? Our mercury experiment seems to contradict this explanation, at least a little.

What about wicking?  If one end of a strip of paper is dipped into water, the water diffuses up through the strip.  If the water is just diffusing into the roots, then couldn't the xylem tubes just fill up with water when it overflows from the tissues that absorb it?  Motion of the tree cause by wind could be squeezing the water into the xylem tubes where it gets further absorbed up the trunk.

The continuous water-column idea doesn't sound plausible because a tree doesn't start gushing water out of the trunk if you notch a hole in it. 

edit:  I also don't think trees are siphoning water out of the ground and evaporating it into the air as much as this video suggests.  I think it's more like the trees wick water out of the ground when the ground is wetter than the inside of the tree, but when the ground is getting dry, moisture flows back into the ground from the tree.  Likewise, trees and plants use the water that's in them for cell reproduction and then when it rains, the plant is poised to absorb the rain because many cells have divided and become drying by using the water available in the plant. 

Plants are busy converting sunlight into chemical energy in the form of sugars and other carbohydrates, amino acids, etc.  If the sunlight shining on them was just heating them up, there would be more evaporation but by maintaining  lower temperature, they can retain their water and use it for nutrient transport, which is how the solar energy is being used as it is absorbed instead of the tree cooling itself through evaporation.

The shade created by the tree also helps prevent plants and soil underneath it from drying out.  Very hardy grasses and other plants can take very strong direct sunlight without breaking down and evaporating their water content, but if it weren't for trees and the partial shade they produce, many plants would fry in the sun, causing their chemical processes to stop, which would lead to the ground heating up and drying out, which would ultimately result in desert-like ground.

I think that a very significant component of this has been inadvertently excluded. Trees do no transport water as water. Trees transport xylem sap.  Sap in northern hemisphere conifers has physical properties that make this transport process more likely to happen and maintain itself.  The sap of these 100 meter conifers is more viscous than water, contains volatile organic compounds that evaporate and transpire at lower temperatures, and ions that interact with the vesicle structures, and oxidative components that reseal the system in the event of injury. You are never going to cut through the cambium layer of a tree and see a gushing of water, it is sap.  We also do not know if there are any electrical processes at work that might provide additional directional hydrodynamic transport force.  It is interesting but incomplete at this point, I do not believe that this is a pure water hydraulic phenomena, nor should it be explained as such.

The easiest way to explain the way in which water is sucked up from the roots and to the leaves is to think of the process in reverse. At the end of the waters journey the excess water found in the air spaces inside the leaf is released through the leaves stomata into the atmosphere, this water is then replaced by water evaporated from the surface of the mesophyll cells, this process causes a transpirational pull and lowers the cells water potential, this in turn allows for the mesophyll cells to take water from neighbouring cells through the waters potential gradient. This process of water loss connects back to the tracheids (water conducting cells found within Xylem) and causes water to be taken from the Xylem, this water then travels along the tracheids into the air within the leaf following the water potential gradient. Xylem travels up the stem of the tree by the action of a water potential gradient, water moves from an area of high potential, to an area of low potential, gradually moving water up from the roots. Waters natural cohesive and adhesive properties and the small diameter of Xylem aid in its movement up the stem.

Dr Poliakoff and Henry were onto something, though. The xylem *is* divided into segments; this ensures that when cavitation bubbles do form, they're contained within that segment and can't vaporize the rest of the water column.

This system is horribly inefficient. Only plants in wet climates can stand to leave this system on all the time otherwise they would rapidly dry out and die.
Some plants in hot climates have to close their stomata during the day (i.e. when they can photosynthesise) because the hot weather would cause them to lose far too much water. As such they must separate CO2 absorption and photosynthesis to prevent excessive water loss. This is what cacti do.
Source: degree in plant science

I suggest it is the hundreds of thousands of positively pressurized hydrostatic vessels. Like a pressurized fire hose, these pressurized xylem tubes act like the rigid supporting stays. They act to keep erect these high towers.

Compare a cross section of a tree trunk to that of our human Pressure Amplifier, and Pressure Receptor - the Pacinian Corpuscle. 
The striking appearance of the Pacinian Corpuscle is remarkably similar to the tree's concentrically arranged Pressure Compartments.
Each year another tree ring is added - hence the potential height of the central liquid column is further elevated.
Laplace’s Law governs these compartments.This law clarifies the amplification effect on the most central compartments.

No pumping required! With the 4 concentrically arranged leg pressure compartments, there is a stepped increase in pressure of 20 mmHg. Hence if you cannulate the most central muscle compartment (pressurized to 780 mmHg) you can elevate a column of water 780/760 x 10.33 = 10.60 m. That is 27 cm above the max possible elevation with a non- compartmentalized object. Add a 20 mmHg compression sock - possible water column height further increases. Now add a compression sock (20 mm) to this leg that is already pressurized to 760 mmHg. Now the vessels in the dermis are pressurized to 790 mm, and the central vessels are pressurized to 800 mmHg. My symbol to the left represents the 4 concentrically arranged leg pressure compartments, with the blood vessels passing through. The first pressure interface is the skin. The first compartment is the dermis (10 mmHg), the fascia is the next interface -- 15 mmHg, then the muscle compartment is 18 mmHg, and finally the central muscle is 20 mmHg. Converting these relative pressures to absolute pressures (as we are immersed in our ocean of Air Pressure) we must add 760 mmHg to these 4 compartments

When you cut a plant stem, you do break the water column and the water boils, filling the xylem with air. Fortunately, the plant can cope because the cells in the xylem are separated by perforated discs. This allows the plant to confine the air to a single cell, which it can later refill with water. This has had to evolve because the water column also spontaneously snaps under high tension (such as in drought conditions).

I believe you mean gases ;) Pressure in a gas is measured differently than "pressure" in liquids and solids... In a gas it's literally the bouncing of molecules off the side of the container... No gas molecules, no collisions = 0 pressure... Whereas this concept is impossible in a liquid, the negative pressure is more akin to tension (as mentioned in the video) The scenario you proposed breaks down, because gases 1. have negligible-0 intermolecular forces and 2. will expand to fill the container

No this is incorrect.

If the pipe is straight up/down,  the bottom is atmospheric pressure, and the top a vacuum, the height of the water column can go up to 10.3m. And within limitations, it doesn't matter how wide this pipe is.

The reason is the atmosphere is *pushing* itself in to --fill the vacuum-- at the top. Its like a vacuum inside a container with hard shell. The atmosphere is trying to get in, and will push equally on all parts of this container. Weak point on shell  is water column

And you still can't "draw up" more than 10m height of water using a conventional approach to the problem. 

As PhsyicsManual suggested, the opposite reaction to a falling column of sugary water is the gravitational force exerted by the water on the WHOLE Earth.

Hello is anyone listening? Guess not but in case someone is. Evaporation from the leaves concentrates sugars produced by the leaves and solutes from the soil, making the sap denser / heavier than the sap at the bottom of the tree. Gravity dictates this denser sap must migrate towards the ground but for every action there must be an equal and opposing reaction. This means that the sap flowing down will cause molecular drag pulling up the less dense sap in the xylem, which draws in water from soil

You can use a sealed syringe to create positive and negative pressures in a liquid. Pushing on the plunger compresses the fluid, and a positive pressure builds up. If a small air bubble is trapped within the syringe, it shrinks as the pressure increases. Pulling on the plunger causes the fluid to develop a tension, or negative pressure. Any air bubbles in the syringe will expand as the pressure is reduced.

Precisely.

The gas laws only apply to gasses with molecules that behave "like billiard balls".  I.e. no intermolecular forces when not in contact, and perfect elastic collisions upon contact.  Also, molecules need be significantly small compared to spacing.  That is what defines an "ideal gas" for which the standard gas law equations apply.

Liquids are entirely what they are, BECAUSE of intermolecular forces, close molecule spacing, and a lack of an ordered crystal structure.

Titanic had multiple sections struck by the iceberg.  The deal is, they spot the berg at a critically unlucky moment & reacted too soon.

See it one minute earlier, they'd steer clear and it'd be a normal day for them.

See it one minute later, they'd hit it head-on and only flood one chamber.  The ship would no longer continue with its journey, but it would stay afloat and most people would survive for rescue.

But instead, it hit the iceberg in a sideswipe, and flooded multiple chambers.

It isn't as if there is a limit at two positive atmospheres of semen pressure, the semen pressure can be as high as your body parts are structurally capable of producing.

I don't think water's tensile strength is anywhere near, even the common steel used in structural cables.  The challenge of the space elevator, is that you need tensile strength (force per unit area), with minimal material's inertia, so that the cable remains mostly taunt.  That is why nanotechnology is thought to be the solution.

The difference between a solid in tension and a liquid in tension, is that the liquid in tension will be hydrostatic, having all three tension stresses equal with negligible shear.  A solid in tension can have a full tensor of unique stress values, three independent tensions and three independent shears (with a symmetry to them, as there is to all shear stress).

A vacuum is actually felt as a "suck", because it is a lack of the familiar atmospheric "push" that you are accustomed to feeling continuously.  When an item is sucked in a vacuum hose, it is really air from the background pushing it up.

Negative pressure by contrast, actually is a tension.  The positive hydrogen half of one H2O can put a tension force on the negative lone pair oxygen half of the oxygen half of another H2O.

“new DNA having completely novel functions, like nylonase”
The gene which received the mutation originally coded for an enzyme that broke down a substance that is chemically similar to nylon. Then a point-mutation in this gene slightly altered it (“broke it” is better) which allowed it to break down a substance (nylonase) which is very similar to the substance it normally breaks down. Not only no new information was added, but it also was a degenerative change causing less specificity.

If animals could gain DNA, they wouldn't survive. Let's take a couple baby dinos for example. The first is born with a cross between a bird's lungs and a reptile's. This one can't breath right, so he can't outrun predators and gets eaten. The second is a cross in bone structure. This one isn't for running or flying, so he breaks his bones and is eaten. This one has the instincts, but is wasting time trying to fly, so he get's eaten. The last has big feathers that get in the way, so he's eaten.

Oh, and with the lung thing. Did dinosaurs have air sacs? No. Did they have hollow bones with cross-structures? No. Did they have the proper muscles in order to drive the respiratory system? No. Did they have the proper bone arrangement? No.

Using a punnet square, let's take the example of the start of all canine creatures. Let's say it had medium length hair to survive in it's environment. As the DNA strand loses genes, it causes the hair to get shorter or longer as time progresses. The longer-haired ones will survive northern climates, while shorter-haired ones will survive tropical climates. This applies to all features of animals, but with loss of DNA, the perfect creatures have degenerated into what they are today.

temps that near boiling, the opposite occurs and the thermal energy of the molecules causes them to bounce off one another and move further apart. The best way to think about it is as a balancing game of thermal versus electric energy. Water is densest at 4C, right before it freezes.

CONT
The reason for this bizarre behavior has to do with thermal energy and polarity. The polarity of water is at just the right point such that faster moving warm molecules (to a point) are able to get closer to each other before electronegative reactions push them apart. In other words, the thermal  energy overcomes the repulsive forces and the water molecules pack more densely. As the molecules slow down, the electric forces take over and hold the molecules part. Of course, at higher CONT2

Actually, this surface tension as a result of cohesion is only part of the reason that ice floats on water. The other part is density. Unlike most substances, water is less dense when solid than when liquid. This is because liquid water is free to move about, allowing hydrogen bonds to break and reform and thus allowing water molecules to come into closer contact. Forming a solid means shoring up all bonds in a repeating pattern, which makes the molecules unable to pack densely. CONT

when we talk about pressure, we think about the molecules pushing off each other and their container. In a gas, if you eliminate all of the molecules, there is nothing pushing on the walls of the container so the pressure=0, a vacuum. But in a liquid, you can make the molecules pull on each other and the walls of their container. Imagine having a sealed piston containing a liquid, as you pull the piston out, the liquid molecules would pull on each other and their surroundings - negative pressure

If the feature DOESN'T help it survive, the tree dies, and we don't see it today.

An explanation for the negative pressures which are observed in the Xylem. (from Wikipedia)
___
When attractive forces (e.g., van der Waals forces) between the particles of a fluid exceed repulsive forces. Such scenarios are generally unstable since the particles will move closer together until repulsive forces balance attractive forces. Negative pressure exists in the transpiration pull of plants, and is used to suction water even higher than the ten meters that it rises in a pure vacuum.

If the diameter of the tube is sufficiently small, then the combination of surface tension (which is caused by cohesion within the liquid) and adhesive forces between the liquid and container act to lift the liquid. Under a vacuum water will lift to the same hight regardless of tube size.

G'day, when he said that he was referring to capillary action (without the assistance of a vacuum) which is the ability of a liquid to flow in narrow spaces without the assistance of, and in opposition to external forces like gravity. It occurs because of inter-molecular attractive forces between the liquid and solid surrounding surfaces.

There is actually a deeper reason for this...competition.

The Competitive reason is because a tree can only get enough light for photosynthesis in a forest if that tree is tall enough to not be over-shadowed completely by other trees competing for light.

The co-operative by product is rainforests: with all this excess moisture in the air the forest has become a superorganism dabbling in weather control for the sake of the whole.  Crazy eh?
